description: From Latin jussus, perfect participle of jubeō (variant of iubeō), 'to order, command'. Related to Latin iūs, 'law, order'.

entries.meaning: (grammar) Of or in the jussive mood.
(grammar, uncountable and countable) The jussive mood, a verb inflection used to indicate a command, permission or agreement with a request; an instance of a verb so inflected.
examples: For example, in the Aaronide blessing, only two of the six verbs are formally jussives, yet all have the same volitional sense.

entries.meaning: (Arabic grammar) A verbal mood of vague or miscellaneous senses, occurring after some particles and in conditional clauses.
